node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
How can war criminals be brought to justice? And what is the role of interpreters within institutions like the International Criminal Court? Host Anne McElvoy asks Katie Kitamura on this week’s “The Economist Asks” podcast.⁠
⁠
Also on the episode, the author of “Intimacies” reveals why she drew inspiration from the ICC and its interpreters for her new book. She explores the power of language and the pitfalls of mistranslation. As the daughter of immigrants to the US, Ms Kitamura talks about where she feels most at home and the secret to marital bliss.⁠
⁠
To hear whether Anne and Katie still have faith in the International Criminal Court, click the link in our bio to listen to “The Economist Asks”.

May be an image of text that says 'Vaccine inequality will cost money as well as lives Forecast GDP losses because of delayed vaccination, $bn* Asia-Pacific Sub-Saharan Africa Middle East & North Africa Eastern Europe Latin America 100 200 300 2022 400 500 600 2023 700 2024 2025 *At market-exchange rates Source: The Economist Intelligence Unit The Economist'.

node.text:
The speedy development of covid-19 vaccines speaks to the best of humanity’s qualities: resilience, ingenuity and the ability to jointly overcome problems.⁠
⁠
Their distribution, however, reflects less well on humankind. ⁠
⁠
By late August around 60% of people in higher-income countries had received at least one dose of a vaccine. In poorer countries only 1% had.⁠
⁠
That is not simply unjust, or dangerous: it could have an economic cost, too. ⁠
⁠
A new report by the Economist Intelligence Unit calculates how much countries that have inoculated less than 60% of their population stand to lose in 2022 and 2025 compared with a scenario in which they achieve higher vaccination rates more quickly.⁠
⁠
As this chart shows, the brunt of the shortfall will be felt by poor countries. How can the vaccine-access gap be bridged to avoid such outcomes? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 05, 2021. May be a closeup of 1 person and outdoors.

node.text:
People often wondered why Gino Strada led the life he did. ⁠
⁠
With his skills as a heart-and-lung surgeon, he could have settled in a pleasant villa somewhere beyond the city, working at an easy pace and growing the roses he loved. ⁠
⁠
Instead he seemed to live in operating theatres in desperate places, draining, cleaning, cutting and suturing the worst wounds imaginable. ⁠
⁠
The reality of war for ordinary people, the fact that they bore the brunt of it, shocked Mr Strada deeply. So did the fact that health care in war-prone places scarcely existed—he believed health care was a human right. ⁠
⁠
He dreamt of a time when talking would replace fighting, and when war would seem as unthinkable as slavery. ⁠
⁠
Gino Strada, war surgeon and hospital-builder, died on August 13th, aged 73. Tap the link in bio to read our obituary. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Pier Marco Tacca/Getty Images

node.text:
Something has gone very wrong with Western liberalism.⁠
⁠
At its heart classical liberalism believes human progress is brought about by debate and reform. ⁠
⁠
The best way to navigate disruptive change in a divided world is through a universal commitment to individual dignity, open markets and limited government.⁠
⁠
Yet a resurgent China sneers at liberalism for being selfish, decadent and unstable. At home, populists on the right and left rage at liberalism for its supposed elitism and privilege.⁠
⁠
Over the past 250 years classical liberalism has helped bring about unparalleled progress. It will not vanish in a puff of smoke. But to read why it is now undergoing a severe test—and why classical liberals must fight back, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover illustration: @dougchayka

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 05, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
In the 21st century, do great novels need grand themes? Or can they still be written about the miscommunication and love affairs of enchanting 20-somethings?⁠
⁠
This is the fundamental question posed by Sally Rooney’s novels. In the latest, “Beautiful World, Where Are You”, she raises it herself.⁠
⁠
In the new book, the two main characters debate the purpose of fiction—in particular, whether the fiction of feelings, the kind in which they appear, is essentially unethical.⁠
⁠
One of them, Alice, is a young novelist whose career resembles Ms Rooney’s. “Who can care,” she asks, “what happens to the novel’s protagonists, when it’s happening in the context of the increasingly fast, increasingly brutal exploitation of a majority of the human species? Do the protagonists break up or stay together? In this world, what does it matter?”⁠
⁠
When the world is burning and the future is bleak, these qualms are understandable. But they are mistaken, argues our Back Story columnist.⁠
⁠
Great novels can do without politics, and need no justification. Click the link in bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Enda Bowe/Hulu

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text.

node.text:
If rich countries do not redistribute surplus vaccine this year, between 1m and 2.8m lives could be lost, according to new analysis by Airfinity, a life-sciences data firm. ⁠
⁠
As it stands, in low-income countries less than 2% of adults are fully vaccinated, compared with 50% in high-income ones. Data show that G7 countries could redistribute 500m doses this month, and up to 1.2bn doses by the end of the year.⁠
⁠
If the current rate of production continues there will be a glut of covid-19 vaccine by the middle of next year. Yet Covax, the biggest buyer and supplier of vaccines to poorer countries, has struggled to get hold of doses it has bought. ⁠
⁠
The two-speed world means that as cases of Delta surge everywhere, the burden of death is falling heavily on the poorest. But tap the link in our bio to learn how vaccine redistribution could save more than 1m lives.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 04, 2021. May be an image of flower.

node.text:
Earth’s past, present and future cannot be understood without appreciating the planet’s biological aspects. ⁠
⁠
The idea that Earth is in some way alive has been a theme in science for centuries. Its modern form, though, dates from the 1960s and the insights of Dr James Lovelock.⁠
⁠
Using definitions of the science of heat, work and order, he concluded that the most detectable such order, at a planetary level, would be found in the composition of the atmosphere.⁠
⁠
The “Gaia hypothesis” was highly controversial but the views of Dr Lovelock, his followers and his opponents have since evolved.⁠
⁠
When it comes to life on planet Earth, who really calls the shots? Tap the link in our bio to read our final of six biology briefs about living planets.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @danieliev

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in San Salvador.

node.text:
⁠Bitcoin is about to become legal tender in El Salvador, alongside the dollar.⁠
⁠
The Central American country of 6.5m people is the first to attempt such a feat.⁠
⁠
A new law says that businesses must accept the cryptocurrency as payment for goods or services.⁠
⁠
Yet three-quarters of Salvadoreans surveyed in July were sceptical of the plan. Two-thirds were not willing to be paid in it and just under half knew nothing about it.⁠
⁠
Both the World Bank and the IMF have warned against adoption. So why is the country doing it? To read what might be behind the move, and whether it will work, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Jose Cabezas

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business In the metaverse, will big gaming eventually become big tech?'.

node.text:
The idea of the “metaverse” is in vogue in Silicon Valley and the next big thing on the internet. No one quite knows what it means. ⁠
⁠
Tim Sweeney, the founder of Epic Games, talks of the metaverse with a “good v greedy” narrative.⁠
⁠
Using virtual and augmented reality, avatars and lifelike computer imagery, the metaverse will further erase the boundaries between people’s online and physical lives. Unsurprisingly, big tech is salivating at the prospect of yet more realms of human existence open to data extraction. ⁠
⁠
Epic’s fight against Apple and Google is about more than just app stores. Its vision of the “metaverse”, where no big company is dominant, looks appealing. But how realistic—or sincere—is it? Tap the link in our bio to find out. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @brett.ryder.illustration

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 04, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The Economist explains How do footballers get their shirt numbers? A RONALDO'.

node.text:
Manchester United have confirmed that Cristiano Ronaldo will wear his famous number seven shirt after returning to Old Trafford. But how are footballers assigned their shirt numbers?⁠
⁠
In England in the 19th century, football players would appear without a number. Instead, they were identified by their position on the pitch.⁠
⁠
It was only in the 1930s that shirt numbers became compulsory in England's top flight. Since then the rules for the use of numbers has evolved with tactics. ⁠
⁠
But today many footballers are making a number their own. Tap the link in the bio as we explain the history behind shirt numbers.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ross Kinnaird/Getty Images

node.text:
Feed stores across America are experiencing a surge in demand for ivermectin, a deworming drug for horses and other livestock.⁠
⁠
Ivermectin’s rise parallels that of hydroxychloroquine, another much-touted covid-19 “cure”. This is despite limited evidence that can it help and significant evidence showing that it can be very harmful. ⁠
⁠
Poison control lines, set up to dispense information and handle emergencies, are swamped with calls.⁠
⁠
A new poll conducted by YouGov for The Economist finds that 26% of Republicans (roughly the same proportion as independents) and 33% of conservatives believe that ivermectin is a “possibly” or “very” effective treatment. Despite the fact it's not proven it works. Tap the link in the bio to read more.
